The towering cliffs overlooking Big Trout Bay, on the north shore of Lake Superior near the U.S.-Canada border, are home to the peregrine falcon. This majestic bird, once nearly extinct in southern Canada, is assessed as special concern by the Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada.

 
The Government of Canada is investing $2.3 million to help Nature Conservancy of Canada / Conservation de la nature Canada to protect over 1,000 pristine hectares around Big Trout Bay, which includes important breeding habitat for the peregrine falcon. http://ow.ly/1Ogh30anEJJ

Did you know the headwaters region of the South Saskatchewan River Basin, located in southwestern Alberta, covers only 4% of the province's area but provides fresh drinking water and groundwater recharge to 45% of Albertans?

To help protect this vital resource, Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada / Conservation de la nature Canada to conserve an additional 917 hectares of ranch land in the foothills region of Alberta. These lands will be protected in perpetuity under the Government of Canada‚Äôs Ecological Gifts Program for future generations to enjoy and benefit. http://ow.ly/q9K630alyWl

Let‚Äôs celebrate #WorldMeteorologicalDay today! It marks the launch of a new edition of the World Meteorological Organization's International Cloud Atlas. 

Clouds are one of the key uncertainties in the study of climate change:  we need to better understand how clouds affect the climate and how a changing climate will affect clouds. The new Atlas contains hundreds of images of clouds, including a few newly classified cloud types. It also features other meteorological phenomena such as rainbows, halos, snow devils and hailstones. Check it out: http://ow.ly/1MNb30aaBMc

While most Canadians only hear about the National Energy Board‚Äôs involvement at the beginning of projects, we actually regulate Canada‚Äôs federal energy infrastructure throughout its entire life cycle. 

We do not simply make a decision on a project and walk away. When approved projects are being built and operated, we inspect and audit them. caption_original:
#WorldEnvironmentDay ‚Äì June 5, 2017 ‚Äì is a chance to celebrate Canada‚Äôs biodiversity!

Biodiversity ‚Äì the life forms we experience all around us, yet know remarkably little about. This wide array of ecosystems, ecological processes, species and genes is essential to our existence. Even as scientists discover new species (estimates suggest millions remain unknown), it is clear that our biodiversity is under threat ‚Äì from competing land uses, pollution, population growth and human activities.

Environment and Climate Change Canada and its partners work to conserve our biodiversity. Find out what we are doing to address this daunting global challenge. http://ow.ly/A8ds309wasW #WED2017
